docs.title: Custom Q App with Jira Plugin
docs.text:
Welcome — this documentation describes how to create a custom Q application, connect it to Jira, configure the Jira app/OAuth permissions, and launch & test the integration.

Prerequisites - Access to the Q platform (developer account / admin access to create custom apps). - Jira access: admin permissions in the Jira site (Cloud or Server/Data Center) where you will register the app. - A local development environment with: Git, Node.js (or language runtime used by your Q app), and curl. - An RSA keypair (if using OAuth 1.0a with RSA) or OAuth client credentials (if using OAuth 2.0 3LO).

Docs structure - 1. Create custom Q app: create-custom-q-app.md - 2. Create the data connection with Jira: create-data-connection-with-jira.md - 3. Create Jira app & OAuth: create-jira-app-oauth.md - 4. Launch & Test: launch-and-test.md

If you need me to commit these files to the repository, tell me and I will push them to docs/ (or open a PR).

docs.title: 1. Create the custom Q app
docs.text:
This page walks through creating a custom Q application (skeleton) that will integrate with Jira.

  1. Plan the integration
  2. Decide which Jira operations you need: create issues, update issues, delete issues, query issues, comments, transitions, webhooks, etc.

  3. Choose authentication method: OAuth 1.0a (RSA) for Server/DC, OAuth 2.0 (3LO) for Jira Cloud, or an API token (Cloud) for non-OAuth flows.

  4. Create the new app in Q (high-level steps)

  5. Sign in to your Q developer console.
  6. Create a new app/project and give it a name like custom-q-jira-integration.

  7. Set a redirect URI (if using OAuth 2.0) to your app's callback endpoint, e.g. https://<your-app>/auth/callback.

  8. App skeleton (example)

  9. Create a repository or local project:
  10. Initialize project: git init custom-q-jira-integration
  11. Create basic files: package.json, src/ (or the language equivalent)
  12. Add configuration placeholders for Jira:
  13. JIRA_BASE_URL
  14. JIRA_AUTH_METHOD (e.g., oauth1, oauth2, api_token)
  15. JIRA_CONSUMER_KEY (OAuth 1.0a)
  16. JIRA_PRIVATE_KEY (PEM) — store in a secure secret store
  17. JIRA_CLIENT_ID / JIRA_CLIENT_SECRET (OAuth 2.0)

  18. CALLBACK_URL (OAuth redirect URI)

  19. Secrets and storage

  20. Never store private keys or client secrets in plaintext in repo.

  21. Use Q platform secrets or your cloud provider secret manager for private keys and client secrets.

  22. Add Jira client code

  23. Implement a thin wrapper around Jira REST API (or use an existing SDK).
  24. Example endpoints to implement:
  25. createIssue(payload)
  26. updateIssue(issueId, payload)
  27. deleteIssue(issueId)

  28. getIssue(issueId)

  29. Local dev notes

  30. Use environment file .env for local testing (but do not commit).
  31. Example .env:
  32. JIRA_BASE_URL=https://your-domain.atlassian.net
  33. JIRA_AUTH_METHOD=oauth2
  34. JIRA_CLIENT_ID=
  35. JIRA_CLIENT_SECRET=
  36. CALLBACK_URL=http://localhost:3000/auth/callback

    37. Next - Proceed to create the Jira data connection (next doc) and register the Jira app / OAuth credentials.

docs.title: 2. Create the data connection with Jira
docs.text:
This page explains how to configure the data connection between your Q app and Jira (the runtime integration configuration and required settings).

  1. Determine Jira endpoint
  2. Jira Cloud example: https://your-domain.atlassian.net

  3. Jira Server example: https://jira.company.internal

  4. Choose authentication method (summary)

  5. OAuth 1.0a (RSA-SHA1): common for Jira Server/Data Center. Uses consumer key + RSA private key.
  6. OAuth 2.0 (3LO): Jira Cloud recommended for user-delegated access with scopes.

  7. API Token (Cloud): basic auth with email + API token (less ideal for production).

  8. Configure connection values in Q app

  9. Environment variables (example):
  10. JIRA_BASE_URL=https://your-jira-instance
  11. JIRA_AUTH_METHOD=oauth1 # or oauth2, api_token
  12. JIRA_CONSUMER_KEY=your-consumer-key
  13. JIRA_PRIVATE_KEY_PATH=/secrets/jira_private_key.pem
  14. JIRA_CLIENT_ID=...
  15. JIRA_CLIENT_SECRET=...
  16. JIRA_API_USER_EMAIL=...

  17. JIRA_API_TOKEN=...

  18. Example: making authorized REST calls

  19. OAuth2-acquired access_token:

  20. curl -X POST "https://your-domain.atlassian.net/rest/api/3/issue" \ -H "Authorization: Bearer " \ -H "Content-Type: application/json" \ -d '{ "fields": { "project": {"key":"PROJ"}, "summary":"Test", "issuetype":{"name":"Task"} } }'

  21. OAuth1 (RSA) — use your Jira client library to sign requests with the private key. Example libraries: oauth-1.0a (Node), requests-oauthlib (Python with RSA support).

  22. Scopes & permissions (OAuth2)

  23. Request scopes required for your operations:
  24. For issue CRUD: read:jira-work write:jira-work
  25. For comments or transitions: additional scopes as required.

  26. Always request the least-privilege scope set.

  27. Webhooks (optional)

  28. If you need event-driven sync (issue updates in Jira push to Q):
  29. Register webhooks in Jira to point to https://<your-app>/webhooks/jira.

  30. Verify webhook signing if available; otherwise validate requests by origin and secrets.

  31. Retry & rate-limiting

  32. Implement retries with exponential backoff for 429/5xx responses.
  33. Respect Jira rate limits.

    34. Next - Register the Jira app and set OAuth configuration in Jira (see next doc).

docs.title: 3. Create the Jira app & configure OAuth permissions
docs.text:
This document covers the steps to register your Q application in Jira and configure OAuth so the Q app can access Jira on behalf of users.

Note: Jira Cloud and Jira Server/Data Center have different flows. Choose the one that applies.

A. Jira Cloud — OAuth 2.0 (3LO) 1. Create an OAuth 2.0 (3LO) app in Atlassian Developer Console - Go to developer.atlassian.com/console (Atlassian developer console). - Create a new OAuth 2.0 (3LO) app. - Configure: - Name: Custom Q App - Authorization callback URL: https://<your-app>/auth/callback (or local for dev) - Add required scopes: e.g., read:jira-work, write:jira-work, offline_access (if you need refresh tokens). - Save client ID and secret securely (JIRA_CLIENT_ID, JIRA_CLIENT_SECRET).

  1. Authorization flow
  2. Direct users to:
  3. https://auth.atlassian.com/authorize?audience=api.atlassian.com&client_id=<CLIENT_ID>&scope=read:jira-work%20write:jira-work%20offline_access&redirect_uri=<CALLBACK_URL>&state=<STATE>&response_type=code&prompt=consent
  4. Exchange authorization code for access_token at:
  5. https://auth.atlassian.com/oauth/token (POST with client_id, client_secret, code, redirect_uri)
  6. Store access_token and refresh_token securely. Use refresh_token to renew tokens.

B. Jira Server / Data Center — OAuth 1.0a with RSA (common) 1. Generate RSA keypair - Generate private key (PEM) and public key: - openssl genrsa -out jira_app_privatekey.pem 2048 - openssl rsa -in jira_app_privatekey.pem -pubout -out jira_app_publickey.pem

  1. Create an Application Link in Jira
  2. As a Jira admin, go to Jira Administration -> Applications -> Application Links.
  3. Enter your Q app base URL and create link.
  4. Edit the new Application Link and configure OAuth (incoming authentication), set:
  5. Consumer Key: a unique consumer key (e.g., custom-q-app)
  6. Consumer Name: friendly name

  7. Public Key: paste content of jira_app_publickey.pem

  8. Capture the consumer key and configure your Q app

  9. In your Q app configuration:
  10. JIRA_AUTH_METHOD=oauth1
  11. JIRA_CONSUMER_KEY=custom-q-app

  12. JIRA_PRIVATE_KEY_PATH=/secrets/jira_app_privatekey.pem (store this securely)

  13. User authorization

  14. To get an access token, you will perform the OAuth dance:
  15. Request request_token from Jira OAuth endpoint.
  16. Redirect the user to Jira to authorize the request_token.
  17. Exchange the authorized request_token for an access token.
  18. Use an OAuth library that supports RSA-SHA1 signing.

Permissions & scopes (server) - Jira Server uses application link permissions; make sure the app link is set to allow access to required resources.

C. Test the OAuth setup - Use a REST client (curl/Postman) or your app to perform an authorized request to a simple Jira REST endpoint (GET issue). - For example (OAuth2 bearer token): - curl -H "Authorization: Bearer " "https://your-domain.atlassian.net/rest/api/3/issue/PROJ-1"

Security reminders - Store the private key and client secrets in a secrets manager. - Use HTTPS endpoints for callbacks and webhooks. - Rotate secrets and support revocation if needed.

Next - Configure the Q app to use the credentials you created and run integration tests (see next doc).

docs.title: 4. Launch the Q application and test Jira access (create, update, delete)
docs.text:
This page shows how to start your Q app locally (or in the target environment) and test Jira operations.

  1. Prepare environment
  2. Ensure required env vars/secrets are set:
  3. JIRA_BASE_URL
  4. JIRA_AUTH_METHOD
  5. JIRA_CLIENT_ID / JIRA_CLIENT_SECRET (if oauth2)
  6. JIRA_CONSUMER_KEY / JIRA_PRIVATE_KEY_PATH (if oauth1)
  7. CALLBACK_URL
  8. For local testing, run:
  9. export JIRA_BASE_URL="https://your-domain.atlassian.net"
  10. export JIRA_AUTH_METHOD="oauth2"
  11. export JIRA_CLIENT_ID="..."
  12. export JIRA_CLIENT_SECRET="..."

  13. export CALLBACK_URL="http://localhost:3000/auth/callback"

  14. Start the application

  15. Example Node.js:
  16. npm install
  17. npm run dev
  18. Make sure the server listens on the configured CALLBACK_URL and has routes:
  19. /auth/start (to begin OAuth flow)
  20. /auth/callback (to receive authorization code)
  21. /api/jira/create-issue
  22. /api/jira/update-issue

  23. /api/jira/delete-issue

  24. Test create (example)

  25. Using your app’s proxy endpoint that calls Jira (recommended to ensure the app auth logic is working):

  26. curl -X POST http://localhost:3000/api/jira/create-issue \ -H "Content-Type: application/json" \ -d '{"projectKey":"PROJ","summary":"Test issue from Q app","description":"Created via integration","issueType":"Task"}'

  27. Alternatively directly to Jira (if you have a valid access token):

  28. curl -X POST "https://your-domain.atlassian.net/rest/api/3/issue" \ -H "Authorization: Bearer " \ -H "Content-Type: application/json" \ -d '{"fields":{"project":{"key":"PROJ"},"summary":"Test issue","issuetype":{"name":"Task"}}}'

  29. Test update

  30. Update summary or fields:

  31. curl -X PUT "https://your-domain.atlassian.net/rest/api/3/issue/PROJ-123" \ -H "Authorization: Bearer " \ -H "Content-Type: application/json" \ -d '{"fields":{"summary":"Updated summary from Q app"}}'

  32. Test delete

  33. Delete an issue (note: depending on your workflow you may prefer to transition to Done instead of deleting):

  34. curl -X DELETE "https://your-domain.atlassian.net/rest/api/3/issue/PROJ-123" \ -H "Authorization: Bearer "

  35. Verify results

  36. Confirm in Jira UI that the issue was created, updated, or deleted.

  37. Check your app logs for success/failure responses from Jira. Log request IDs from Jira for troubleshooting.

  38. Automated tests (recommended)

  39. Write unit tests / integration tests that:
  40. Mock Jira responses for CI.
  41. Run real end-to-end tests in a staging environment with a test Jira site.

    42. Troubleshooting - 401 Unauthorized: check token, client credentials, callback URL, or app link configuration. - 403 Forbidden: insufficient permissions / scopes. - 429 Too Many Requests: implement backoff and respect rate limits. - 500/502/503: transient server error — retry.

    Next - After verification, deploy the app to your production environment, ensure secrets are set, and monitor logs and Jira API usage.
